text: Okay all my slasher-flick-cinephiles out there,

this one has been cooked this
one up especially for you.
We’ve all know the feeling of sitting on
the couch, shaking in our boots while stuffing
our faces with popcorn, but have you ever
thought about what it would like to be
in the shoes of a slasher film victim?
Turns out, what’s happening in their brain
is not too different from what’s happening

in your brain when you’re on
the edge of the seat watching.
(Reactions - splash)

Let’s say you’re running from
an axe murderer in hot pursuit.
Obviously you’re going to be in a state
of crushing fear, but before we continue,
let’s talk about what exactly fear is.

Fear is a cognitive response that alerts
us in the face of serious trouble.
Simply put, it results from chemical

processes that gear our bodies up
to get the heck out of danger!
When you perceive possible danger, that
sensory information is sent through
your central nervous system to a region

of the brain that works like a
switchboard called the thalamus.
The thalamus then hustles this signal

over to the the amygdala using a
neurotransmitter called glutamate.
Glutamate-based signaling then transmits the
emergency to these two parts of the brain.
When the signal reaches the periaqueductal

gray, it switches you to a state of
hyperalertness and makes you startled.
Then it’s on to the Hypothalamus which
controls your fight or flight response.
To get you action-ready, the hypothalamus
tells your adrenal glands to start

pumping out adrenaline, amongst
other super powered molecules.
The adrenaline release gets you amped
up and also makes their way to your

liver to trigger a release of
glucose into your bloodstream.

This offers you an extra jolt of
energy, kind of like a sugar rush.
Then cortisol keeps all of these processes

in the fight or flight response
up and running full speed.
But let’s say that these super charged powers
aren’t enough to get you out of danger from

the axe murderer… well that’s
a whole different story.

All good slasher scenes feature
a blood curdling scream.
Screams are actually a primordial automatic
function of the body, and recent
research suggests we perceive screams
in a completely different part of the
brain than language. Unlike normal speech,
screams go from your ears to
the amygdala, the brain’s emergency

center, and can trigger a similar
chemical response in listeners.
It’s almost as though the screamer is
trying to share with you the state
of their horrified brain chemistry.
Obviously that scream isn’t going to
magically stop that axe that’s headed
right for you, so what next?
Pain is a feeling, but it’s a little
different from our sense of touch.
When you’re injured sensory neurons
specific to pain called nociceptors send
this message up your spinal cord and into
your central nervous system where it is
relayed to the thalamus.
The thalamus is the part of your brain

that delegates your pain-related,
neurological responsibilities.
Pain lets your bodies know that whatever
just happened needs to not happen again.
It’s all about self preservation, and you
get the message… it hurts for a reason!
So now you’re on the floor, dead as
a rock thanks to Mr. Axe murderer.
Assuming no massive brain damage was
inflicted, at this point you would be

considered clinically dead - that
is, your heart’s gone kaput
and you certainly aren’t breathing.
Your brain on the other hand is still working,
and recent research has shown that during
this period, your brain can enter into a
hyper-state of perceptual neural activity.
Some even believe that this could be an
explanation of near death experiences.
Well then folks, once you’ve seen the light,
it really means it’s time for lights out
soon your brain will shut down for good, in
what’s known as biological death, and it
is the last stop on the slasher train.
So think about it the next time you hear

that blood curdling scream in
your favorite horror film:
Once the damage is done, they might very
well be lying on the ground, reliving
the entirety of the movie in their

head thanks to that all that
near-death neural activity.
